title: How to Prepare Watercolor Paper

steps.headline: Wear a pair of latex gloves to avoid damage to the paper.
steps.description: The gloves are useful because the paper is very delicate in water. It can take on skin oil and fingerprints. These marks show through any paint you use later.

steps.headline: Fill a flat-bottomed tray with cold water.
steps.description: You will need a flat surface to hold the paper, such as your sink or bathtub. You can use any tub or tray with a flat bottom. To avoid damaging the paper, use water that is no warmer than room temperature. You can use trays that are smaller than the paper. Dip the paper in 1 side at a time until the paper is dampened evenly. If you don’t have a tray at all, you can use a spray bottle to dampen the paper.

steps.headline: Soak the paper in the water for at least 3 minutes.
steps.description: Submerge the paper, laying it flat against the bottom of the tray. Check the paper’s packaging to find out the sheet weight. Soak sheets marked 90 lb (41 kg) for 3 minutes. 140 lb (64 kg) paper will take about 8 minutes. The soaking time varies depending on the paper. You may need to soak it for longer than 8 minutes. When the paper is soaked enough, the edges will not move if you bend them. It will flatten out if the paper is too dry and droop if the paper is too wet. 300 lb (140 kg) is thick, almost like cardboard. It doesn’t need to be soaked at all.

steps.headline: Move the paper to a sturdy, waterproof board.
steps.description: Use a board that will stay flat throughout the drying process. Many artists opt for polystyrene or Gator Boards, which you can purchase from art or office supply stores. Lay the paper over the board, keeping the side you want to use facing up. You can also try plexiglass, Lexan boards, or marine plywood.

steps.headline: Blot out the excess water with a clean paper towel.
steps.description: While wearing the latex gloves, smooth the paper out to make sure it is flat against the board. This should push out some of the excess water. Dab a paper towel or a sponge all over the sheet to soak up any standing water. Remember, you aren’t drying the paper with the towel or sponge. You only want to absorb and water that would run off the paper.

steps.headline: Dampen gummed paper tape with a paintbrush.
steps.description: Pick up a roll of gummed paper tape from an art or office supply store. Dip a paintbrush into the water, then spread it over the tape. You will need enough tape to cover the paper’s edges. Lightly moisten the tape to avoid washing off the adhesive. Instead of using a paintbrush, you can dip the tape in the water. Quickly dip the tape, then squeeze it between your fingers to drain excess water.

steps.headline: Place the tape over the paper’s borders.
steps.description: Cover about ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) of the paper on all sides. Press the tape down with your fingers to smooth it out. It should stick to the board, holding the paper flat. You can also staple the paper’s edges. This works well if the tape is giving you a hard time.

steps.headline: Dry the paper overnight.
steps.description: Leave the board in a safe spot out in the open, such as on a counter or table. Pick a flat surface so the water dries more evenly. The paper will begin to dry after 2 or 3 hours. You can try standing the board up and rotating it every 20 minutes. This prevents water from pooling around the tape, speeding up the drying process.

steps.headline: Cut away the tape to remove the paper.
steps.description: Place a ruler over the tape, then cut along the edges with an X-Acto knife. Taking off the tape is allows you to remove the paper for storage and reuse the board to prepare more paper. You do lose a little bit of the paper this way and will need to transfer the paper to another painting surface. If you don’t want to cut the paper, try dampening the tape again. If the adhesive gets wet, you may be able to peel the tape off of the paper.

steps.headline: Wear latex gloves to avoid damaging the paper.
steps.description: Wet paper can fall apart on you and absorb the oil in your fingertips. To avoid having fingerprints show through your paint, wear the gloves as you handle the wet paper.

steps.headline: Lay the paper on a flat board.
steps.description: Pick out a polystyrene board, a Gator Board, or something similar. Lay the board on a flat surface, then place the paper on top of it. Make sure the paper is flat.

steps.headline: Brush cold water onto the paper with a paint brush.
steps.description: Use a large paint brush to spread cold water over the entire piece of paper. You cannot use too much water, although you will need to use more water on heavier paper. Continue spreading water until the paper is saturated. When the paper is saturated, it will not hold additional water. Any water you add will run off the page instead of being absorbed.

steps.headline: Turn the page over and add more water.
steps.description: Carefully flip the paper by grasping 2 of the corners. Make sure the paper is flat against the board. Then, use the brush again. Add more water until this side is also saturated. The paper is delicate when it is wet, so handle it as little as possible.

steps.headline: Flip the paper and let it dry for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the paper over so that the original side you dampened is face up. The paper should still be flat against the board. Leave the paper alone for about 15 minutes. Leave the board out in the open on a flat surface so it dries faster.

steps.headline: Roll 2 layers of paper towel over the paper.
steps.description: Make the paper towels even and big enough to cover the paper. Lay the first layer over the sheet of paper, then top it with the second layer. The paper towels will absorb some of the excess moisture right away.

steps.headline: Press the paper towels firmly against the paper.
steps.description: Push down on the paper towels so they squeeze against the paper. Any excess moisture should be forced out of the paper and into the paper towels. When no more water comes out of the paper, throw away the paper towels.

steps.headline: Paint while the paper is still damp.
steps.description: Avoid waiting for the paper to dry. The damp sheet will still hold onto paint almost as well as dried paper, although the colors may soften and blend together more. If you can, prepare your paper in advance by soaking and drying it. You will have more of an opportunity to make sure the paper is perfect.

text: Stretching Paper for Later Wear a pair of latex gloves to avoid damage to the paper. The gloves are useful because the paper is very delicate in water. It can take on skin oil and fingerprints. These marks show through any paint you use later. Fill a flat-bottomed tray with cold water. You will need a flat surface to hold the paper, such as your sink or bathtub. You can use any tub or tray with a flat bottom. To avoid damaging the paper, use water that is no warmer than room temperature. You can use trays that are smaller than the paper. Dip the paper in 1 side at a time until the paper is dampened evenly. If you don’t have a tray at all, you can use a spray bottle to dampen the paper. Soak the paper in the water for at least 3 minutes. Submerge the paper, laying it flat against the bottom of the tray. Check the paper’s packaging to find out the sheet weight. Soak sheets marked 90 lb (41 kg) for 3 minutes. 140 lb (64 kg) paper will take about 8 minutes. The soaking time varies depending on the paper. You may need to soak it for longer than 8 minutes. When the paper is soaked enough, the edges will not move if you bend them. It will flatten out if the paper is too dry and droop if the paper is too wet. 300 lb (140 kg) is thick, almost like cardboard. It doesn’t need to be soaked at all. Move the paper to a sturdy, waterproof board. Use a board that will stay flat throughout the drying process. Many artists opt for polystyrene or Gator Boards, which you can purchase from art or office supply stores. Lay the paper over the board, keeping the side you want to use facing up. You can also try plexiglass, Lexan boards, or marine plywood. Blot out the excess water with a clean paper towel. While wearing the latex gloves, smooth the paper out to make sure it is flat against the board. This should push out some of the excess water. Dab a paper towel or a sponge all over the sheet to soak up any standing water. Remember, you aren’t drying the paper with the towel or sponge. You only want to absorb and water that would run off the paper. Dampen gummed paper tape with a paintbrush. Pick up a roll of gummed paper tape from an art or office supply store. Dip a paintbrush into the water, then spread it over the tape. You will need enough tape to cover the paper’s edges. Lightly moisten the tape to avoid washing off the adhesive. Instead of using a paintbrush, you can dip the tape in the water. Quickly dip the tape, then squeeze it between your fingers to drain excess water. Place the tape over the paper’s borders. Cover about ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) of the paper on all sides. Press the tape down with your fingers to smooth it out. It should stick to the board, holding the paper flat. You can also staple the paper’s edges. This works well if the tape is giving you a hard time. Dry the paper overnight. Leave the board in a safe spot out in the open, such as on a counter or table. Pick a flat surface so the water dries more evenly. The paper will begin to dry after 2 or 3 hours. You can try standing the board up and rotating it every 20 minutes. This prevents water from pooling around the tape, speeding up the drying process. Cut away the tape to remove the paper. Place a ruler over the tape, then cut along the edges with an X-Acto knife. Taking off the tape is allows you to remove the paper for storage and reuse the board to prepare more paper. You do lose a little bit of the paper this way and will need to transfer the paper to another painting surface. If you don’t want to cut the paper, try dampening the tape again. If the adhesive gets wet, you may be able to peel the tape off of the paper. Stretching Paper Immediately Wear latex gloves to avoid damaging the paper. Wet paper can fall apart on you and absorb the oil in your fingertips. To avoid having fingerprints show through your paint, wear the gloves as you handle the wet paper. Lay the paper on a flat board. Pick out a polystyrene board, a Gator Board, or something similar. Lay the board on a flat surface, then place the paper on top of it. Make sure the paper is flat. Brush cold water onto the paper with a paint brush. Use a large paint brush to spread cold water over the entire piece of paper. You cannot use too much water, although you will need to use more water on heavier paper. Continue spreading water until the paper is saturated. When the paper is saturated, it will not hold additional water. Any water you add will run off the page instead of being absorbed. Turn the page over and add more water. Carefully flip the paper by grasping 2 of the corners. Make sure the paper is flat against the board. Then, use the brush again. Add more water until this side is also saturated. The paper is delicate when it is wet, so handle it as little as possible. Flip the paper and let it dry for 15 minutes. Turn the paper over so that the original side you dampened is face up. The paper should still be flat against the board. Leave the paper alone for about 15 minutes. Leave the board out in the open on a flat surface so it dries faster. Roll 2 layers of paper towel over the paper. Make the paper towels even and big enough to cover the paper. Lay the first layer over the sheet of paper, then top it with the second layer. The paper towels will absorb some of the excess moisture right away. Press the paper towels firmly against the paper. Push down on the paper towels so they squeeze against the paper. Any excess moisture should be forced out of the paper and into the paper towels. When no more water comes out of the paper, throw away the paper towels. Paint while the paper is still damp. Avoid waiting for the paper to dry. The damp sheet will still hold onto paint almost as well as dried paper, although the colors may soften and blend together more. If you can, prepare your paper in advance by soaking and drying it. You will have more of an opportunity to make sure the paper is perfect.
